intro: Raphanus boissieri, commonly known as the Armenian radish, is a perennial herb native to the mountains of the Caucasus region. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other cruciferous plants like cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, featuring basal leaves that are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in racemes, and it produces round, fleshy roots that are edible. The plant is adapted to rocky and arid environments, showcasing its resilience in challenging conditions.
